column13: What happened?
The independent Flin Flon Reminder was a daily paper but reduced publication to three times a week as of April 29th 2005. In August 2015, the paper started publishing twice a week.
In early July 2009, the Langley Times, a Black Press community newspaper, dropped its publication schedule from three days to two.
The Penticton Western Daily News ceased daily publication in 2011. Black Press retains its community newspaper in Penticton, which is named the Penticton Western News.
The Surrey Leader Daily, a free daily newspaper owned by Black Press, ceased publishing in 2011.  Black Press retains its community newspaper in Surrey, which is named the Surrey North Delta Leader.
Terrace-Kitimat-Prince Rupert Northern Daily, a free daily newspaper owned by Black Press, ceased publishing in September 2012.
KelownaNow, an online site, first appeared in 2012.
The Dunnville Chronicle and the West Niagara News were closed by Sun Media in November, 2012.
Barrhaven Independent was a weekly that moved to web-only publication in early 2012. It relaunched a print edition in February 2013 that appears twice a month.
La Nouvelle, a Transcontinental community paper, ceased publication in the first quarter of 2012.
Markdale Standard, a Sun Media community newspaper, ceased publication in the third quarter of 2012.
The news section of infotel.ca, which  reports on Vernon, Kelowna, Penticton, and Kamloops, launched at the end of 2012.
In October 2013 Transcontinental  Media closed The Charter, a community paper that had been served Placentia for 16 years.

column5: daily paper - paid : daily becomes a community paper
column13: The Amherst Daily News stopped daily publication and became a weekly newspaper as of Aug. 2, 2013.

The Quebecor-owned Lindsay Post ceased publication in 2013. At the time of closure it appeared twice per week on Tuesdays and Fridays. Back in May 2007, when the paper was owned by Osprey Media, the paper changed its name from The Daily Post to The Lindsay Post to reflect its change from publishing Monday to Friday to Tuesdays and Fridays.
In September 2014 the Oakville Beaver, a Metroland newspaper, cancelled its Wednesday edition. The paper now publishes Thursday and Friday only.
Metro London, a free daily paper launched by Metro Canada on April 4, 2011, closed in late 2014.
In April 2012, Metro Canada launched Metro Regina with a daily print edition, website and mobile apps. It closed in the third quarter of 2014.
In April 2012, Metro Canada launched Metro Saskatoon with a daily print edition, website and mobile apps. It closed in the third quarter of 2014.
The Cape Breton Star is a new community newspaper launched by the  independently-owned Chronicle Herald in May 2014.

column5: daily paper - paid : decrease in service
column13: Halifax Chronicle Herald cancelled its Sunday edition in 2013.
Ottawa RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.
Calgary RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.
Edmonton RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.
Quebecor-owned 24 Heures Gatineau-Ottawa, a free daily newspaper, ceased publication on May 9, 2008.
Armchairmayor.com, a blog run by a former mayor and reporter, added local news coverage when the Kamloops Daily News closed. On August 2, 2015 it transformed into NewsKamloops.com.

Around the Block, a community newspaper that publishes every two months, was established  in 2008.  It features articles written by local residents, and focuses on several neighbourhoods around Saint John.
Jasper Booster, a Sun Media-owned community newspaper, ceased publishing in March 2009.
The Morinville Redwater Town and Country Examiner was born in November 2008 with the merging of the Morinville Mirror and Redwater Tribune. The paper was shuttered several months later.
Red Deer, Alberta, remains one of the largest Canadian cities outside a major metropolitan market to operate without a TV station following the 2009 closure of the local CanWest station.
CTV did not renew the licence for local station CKNX in Wingham, Ontario. It closed on August 2009.

CKX, the only local TV station in Brandon,Manitoba, closed in 2009 after CTV could not find a buyer for the station. CTV put it on the market after CBC chose not to renew its rebroadcasting agreement.
The final print run of the Nelson Daily News was in July 2010. The paper was shut down a few weeks after Black Press purchased it from Glacier Media.
The final print run of the the Prince Rupert Daily News was in July 2010. The paper was shut down a few weeks after Black Press purchased it fom Glacier Media.
column23: Was in the 2009 Newspaper Canada Paid Daily, not in the 2010 list

column13: Whistler Today was a local free daily launched by Glacier Media in 2006.  It was closed in 2011.
Squamish Today was a local free daily that launched by Glacier Media in 2006. It was closed in 2011.
Metro Canada launched Metro London, a free daily paper, on April 4, 2011.
The Saskatoon Express, a new weekly community newspaper, launched in 2011.
CBC radio started a drive home (afternoon) show, based in Kelowna in 2011.
Saint John Newschasers is an online site which publishes local news via Twitter and Facebook.
The LaSalle Silhouette community paper closed in December 2011.
Tecumseh Tribune ceased publication at the beginning of 2012.
The Caledonia Regional News This Week closed at the beginning of 2012.
Grimsby News Now, a weekly community newspaper, launched in 2012.
The Montreal Mirror, a community newspaper owned by Sun Media, was closed in June 2012.

column5: daily paper - paid : decrease in service
column13: The Calgary Herald cancelled its Sunday edition as of June 2012.

column5: daily paper - paid : decrease in service
column13: The Edmonton Journal cancelled its Sunday edition as of June 2012.

column5: daily paper - paid : decrease in service
column13: The Ottawa Citizen stopped publishing a Sunday edition as of June 2012.
Polish newspaper Gazeta (Toronto ed.) was publishing three times per week, but in 2014 it became a weekly.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities, ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
In Nova Scotia, the Chronicle Herald launched a new Cape Breton edition of the paper at the end of March 2014.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
The Amherstburg Echo, one of the oldest newspapers in Canada, closed in October 2012.
CBC radio launched a new morning radio show in Kamloops in 2012.
On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched Ottawa Capital City News, a weekly newspaper. It closed it in December 2012.
West Niagara News was closed by Sun Media in November 2012.
On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched the Guelph Review, a weekly newspaper. It closed at the end of 2012.
On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched the Kitchener-Waterloo Review, a weekly newspaper. It closed by the end of the year.
On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched Windsor This Week, a weekly newspaper in Windsor, Ont.  It closed by the end of the year.
The Sun-owned Leamington Post closed at the end of 2012.

column5: daily paper - paid : daily becomes a community paper
column13: The Sun-owned Daily Graphic became a weekly publication in 2013.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. This did not happen in the case of the Bayview Mills paper.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. The Beach-South Riverdale paper was not relaunched.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. The Bloor West paper was not relaunched.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. The MidTown paper was not relaunched.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. The North York paper was not relaunched.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. The Riverdale-East York paper was not relaunched.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the papers. Toronto Today, which covered downtown Toronto, was not relaunched.
Multimedia Nova went into receivership. Vaughan Today was closed in May 2013.
Rogers cancelled its 24-hour CityNews channel on May 30, 2013. The channel was launched in October 2011.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Midland Free Press, a weekly publication.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Lac du Bonnet Leader, a weekly publication.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Beausejour Review, a weekly publication.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of L'Action Regionale, a weekly publication.
24-7 Red Deer is a community social media site. It was launched in summer of 2013.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of Le Magazine Saint-Lambert, a weekly publication in Quebec.
Sun Media closed the Le Progrès de Bellechasse in July, 2013.
Westbank and District Community Radio is a new community radio station that was launched in July, 2013.
The Tekawennake News, which billed itself as Canada's oldest indigenous weekly paper,  closed in July, 2013.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees and the Forest Hill paper was relaunched. It now publishes every two weeks instead of every week.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees and the Leaside-Rosedale paper was relaunched. It now publishes every two weeks instead of every week.

In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees and the North Toronto paper was relaunched. It now publishes every two weeks instead of every week.
Halifax Daily News, a paid daily paper owned by Transcontinental, closed in early 2008.
Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Calgary paper on August 2nd, 2013.
Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Edmonton paper on August 2nd, 2013.
Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Ottawa paper on August 2nd, 2013.

column2: Two Row Times: the Spirit of All Nations.
column13: Two Row Times was launched in August 2013 soon after the Tekawennake News closed.
The Crowsnest Pass Promoter was closed by Sun Media in August 2013.
In September, the Metroland-owned Etobicoke Guardian, a community paper, cancelled its Tuesday edition. It is now appears once a week on Thursdays.
In September, the Metroland-owned North York Mirror cancelled its Tuesday edition. It is now appears only on Thursdays.
In September, the Metroland-owned Scarborough Mirror community newspaper cancelled its Tuesday edition. It is now appears once a week on Thursdays.
On October 3, 2013, Metroland launched the first edition of the Norfolk News, a weekly newspaper covering Norfolk County.
The Victoria News Daily ceased publication in November 2013. (It is different from the Victoria News,  a community newspaper. )
Black Press closed the Abbotsford Times, a community newspaper, at the end of 2013.
Glacier Media Group closed the Kamloops Daily News on Jan. 11, 2014, leaving British Columbia’s 12th largest city without a daily newspaper.

In response to the impending closure of the Daily News, Thompson River Publications Partnership Ltd. announced that Kamloops This Week would increase its publication dates to three days per week effective January 17, 2014.
Peace Arch News Daily, a Black Press title, ceased publication in March 2014. A community newspaper, called Peace Arch News, remains in circulation.
The Sarnia Journal, a community paper, was launched in March of 2014 by three local business people.
The Black Press daily newspaper, Vernon Morning Star Daily, ceased publication in March 2014. The community newspaper, called Vernon Morning Star, remains in circulation.
The Black Press daily newspaper, Nanaimo News Bulletin Daily ceased publication March 2014. The community newspaper, Nanaimo News Bulletin, remains in publication.
Anishinabek News, a monthly paper that covers First Nations issues, ceased printing hard copies and moved online as of the April 2014 issue.
The Halifax-Examiner, a subscriber-funded online investigative news site, was launched in June 2014.

column5: community paper : closed due to merger
column13: The Bridgewater Bulletin & Lunenburg Progress Enterprise merged to become The Lunenburg County Progress Bulletin in May 2011.
In 2013, the daily TO Night , began appearing  twice a week.  It then closed down entirely in 2014.
Metroland launched the free daily newspaper Metro Halifax in early 2008. It replaced Halifax Daily News.
The Star Media Group's Toronto community newspaper The Grid closed in July 2014.

Locally-produced Voyage North, the CBC radio drive-home show in Thunder Bay, aired its last show on Aug. 11, 2014 and was replaced with a drive-home show produced from Sudbury, Ontario, more than 1,000 kilometres away.
Originally an independent alternative weekly, Here Magazine closed in August 2014.
L’Écho de Victoriaville, a Quebecor publication, competed with Transcontinental's La Nouvelle Union. It was launched in 2012 and closed in September 2014.
Châteauguay Express, launched by Transcontinental in 2011, was closed in September 2014.
L’Impact de Drummondville, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed in September, 2014.
Roussillon Express, a Transcontinental publication, was closed in September, 2014.
Agri-Vallée, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Le Journal de Magog, a Transcontinental community newspaper,  closed in September, 2014.
La Voix de la Matanie, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
La Voix Gaspésienne, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
L’Echo de la Lièvre, a Transcontinental community newspaper,  closed September, 2014.
Point de vue Laurentides, a Transcontinental community newspaper,  closed September, 2014.
L’Écho de Repentigny, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Le Progrès Écho, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Le Rimouskois, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Abitibi Express – Rouyn-Noranda, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed in September, 2014.
L’Écho de Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Le Riverain, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Édition Beauce Nord, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed  in September, 2014.
L’Écho de Shawinigan, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Chambly Express, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Abitibi Express – Val d’Or, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed September, 2014.
Valleyfield Express, a Transcontinental community newspaper,  closed September, 2014. TC Media originally launched the weekly print newspaper (and ValleyfieldExpress.ca) in 2012.
L'Écho de la Rive-Nord, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
L'Écho de Laval, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
L'Écho de Trois-Rivières, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Le Journal de Joliette, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Le Point du Lac-Saint-Jean, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Le Réveil, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Néomédia bought Pub Extra Magazine, a community newspaper, in September 2014 and began publishing it online only.
Néomédia bought the community newspaper the Sorel-Tracy Express, and began publishing it online only in September 2014.
Vallée-du-Richelieu Express, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.
Le Saint-Laurent Portage, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed in September, 2014.
Metroland launched the East Gwillimbury Express, a community newpaper, on September 11, 2014.
The Black Press-owned Kelowna Capital News was a daily newspaper until 2011 when it began publishing three times a week. As of Sept. 15, 2014, it began appearing twice per week.
Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities. ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.
Channel 6, a new online local news outlet serving Central Alberta and Red Deer, was launched May 29, 2015.
Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Hamilton. It closed on December 9, 2014.
Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Kitchener. It closed on December 9, 2014.
Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Victoria. It closed on December 9, 2014.
Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Windsor. It closed on December 9, 2014.
A new monthly community newspaper, the South Cowichan Echo, opened in December, 2014.
This online local news site in Kamloops is owned by the same company that publishes KelownaNow.com. It published its first tweet in January, 2015.
Xtra - Ottawa ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.
Xtra - Vancouver ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.
Xtra - Toronto ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.
The Black Press publication, the Cowichan Valley News Leader Pictoral, switched from daily to weekly publication in March 2013 before finally closing entirely in March 2015.
Fast Forward Weekly first transitioned to an online news source and then closed in March, 2015.
Purchased from Glacier Media, the Oceanside Star was closed by Black Press in March, 2015.
Purchased from Glacier Media, the Campbell River Courier-Islander was closed by Black Press in March, 2015.
Purchased from Glacier Media, the Harbour City Star community paper was closed in April, 2015 by Black Press.
Global News' local Montreal newscast began broadcasting from Toronto as of April 2015.
Previously published twice a week, Niagara This Week began publishing weekly as of May 2015.
The Prince George Free Press, owned by Aberdeen publishing, closed in May 2015.
Rogers cancelled its Breakfast Television show in Edmonton in May 2015.

OMNI Television, the multicultural broadcast wing of Rogers Media Inc., shut down its Punjabi, Mandarin, Cantonese and Italian newscasts in May 2015. The national Punjabi newscast was produced in Vancouver. The newscasts were replaced by current affairs shows in Cantonese, Mandarin and Punjabi that spend more time on each story but do not include original reporting. The Italian newscast was scrapped entirely and replaced with an Italian-language soap opera.

OMNI Television, the multicultural broadcast wing of Rogers Media Inc., shut down its local Punjabi, Mandarin, and Cantonese newscasts in September, 2011, but still contributed local stories to the national newscasts. Finally, all local content stopped in 2013.

OMNI Television, the multicultural broadcast wing of Rogers Media Inc., shut down its Punjabi, Mandarin, Cantonese and Italian newscasts in May 2015. The national Cantonese and Mandarin newscasts were produced in Toronto. The newscasts were replaced by current affairs shows in Cantonese, Mandarin and Punjabi that spend more time on each story but do not include original reporting. The Italian newscast was scrapped entirely and replaced with an Italian-language soap opera.

In the fall of 2012, the Vancouver Province launched VancouverDesi.com, a new website serving  the South Asian community in B.C. It closed in June of 2015, and the url now redirects to the Province's Asia Pacific section.
In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Meadow Lake Progress, a weekly publication.
The Loyalist City Newschasers is a local private Facebook group that publishes news. It started in December, 2013.
Cult MTL is a daily web and monthly print publication focusing on local culture in Montreal. It was founded July 2012 and is run by former employees of the Mirror.
Voir,  a community paper, reduced its publication schedule from weekly to every two weeks in May 2013.
The Hour, a commuity newspaper in Montreal, closed in May 2012.
The Montreal community newspaper ICI, owned by Quebecor, closed in April 2009.
La Ronge Northerner, a Glacier Media community newspaper, ceased publication in August 2015.
Hudson Bay Post Review, a Glacier Media community newspaper, ceased publication in August 2015.
The Mainlander,  a news and views website that bills itself as "Vancouver's Place for Progressive Politics", opened in November 2010.

Global's News at Noon is a new half-hour local newscast produced out of Montreal and hosted by Jamie Orchard. It launched August 17, 2015.

The XPress, owned by Voir Communications, closed down in May 2012.
Roundhouse Radio, a new hyper-local private radio station, launched in September 2015.
The Campbell River/Comox Valley Daily, created in 2011 by Black Press, ceased publishing in December 2013.
The Fraser Valley Daily,  a free newspaper owned by Black Press that covered Chilliwack and Abbotsford, ceased publication in 2013.

column13: In early 2014 Glacier Media merged two daily newspapers in the Peace River region of British Columbia: the Dawson Creek Daily News and the Alaska Highway News in Fort St. John. The company said the Alaska Highway News would expand to cover Dawson Creek, Fort Nelson to the north and the surrounding areas.
The Golden Ears Daily, a Black Press-owned free daily, ceased publication in November, 2013.
Cramahe Now, a hyperlocal news site, launched in March 2009.

column13: In March 2009, Quebecor's Colborne Chronicle, a community paper, ceased to exist because it was merged with the daily Port Hope Guide and the Cobourg Daily Star to create Northumberland Today.

column13: In March 2009, Quebecor's Cobourg Daily Star ceased ceased to exist because it merged with the Port Hope Guide, a daily, and the Colborne Chronicle, a community paper, to create Northumberland Today.

column13: In March 2009, Quebecor daily The  Port Hope Guide ceased to exist  because it merged with the Cobourg Daily Star and the Colborne Chronicle, a community paper, to create Northumberland Today.

column13: The Lunenburg County Progress Bulletin was created through the merger of the Bridgewater Bulletin (est. 1887) and Lunenburg Progress Enterprise (est. 1876) in May 2011. The new publication is a locally owned independent newspaper published every Wednesday by Lighthouse Media Group.
Transcontinental Media launched a new community newspaper in Nova Scotia on November 12. Valley Now is a free weekly publication serving the residents of Kings, Annapolis and Hants counties.

column13: The West Carleton EMC ceased to exist after it was purchased by Metroland and merged with the West Carleton Review to create the West Carleton Review EMC in October 2011.

column13: The Uxbridge Standard ceased to exist after Skyline Media merged it and the Scugog Standard in January 2013 to create The Standard.
